text.wiki:
The Bock (Luxembourgish: Bockfiels) is a promontory in the north-eastern corner of Luxembourg City's old historical district. Offering a natural fortification, its rocky cliffs tower above the River Alzette which surrounds it on three sides. It was here that Count Siegfried built his Castle of Lucilinburhuc in 963, providing a basis for the development of the town which became Luxembourg. Over the centuries, the Bock and the surrounding defences were reinforced, attacked and rebuilt time and time again as the armies of the Burgundians, Habsburgs, Spaniards, Prussians and French vied for victory over one of Europe's most strategic strongholds, the Fortress of Luxembourg. Warring did not stop until the Treaty of London was signed in 1867, calling for the demolition of the fortifications. Ruins of the old castle and the vast underground system of passages and galleries known as the casemates continue to be a major tourist attraction.


== History ==

    
It was in 963 that Count Siegfried, in search of a site from which he could defend his properties, obtained the Bock and its surroundings from St Maximin's Abbey in Trier in exchange for the land he owned at Feulen in the Ardennes to the north. The Romans, then the Franks, had probably already inhabited the Bock although there is only scant archeological evidence of their presence. There are however traces of a 4th-century Roman watchtower close to the point in the Fish Market where two major Roman roads used to cross, one from Reims to Trier and the other from Metz to Liège.

The first historical mention of the Bock is indeed in connection with a watchtower or fortification on the Roman road from Reims to Trier  which, in 723, was ceded by Charles Martel, Duke of the Franks, to the Abbey of St Maximin in Trier. Two centuries later, Count Siegfried, who had properties "in Feulen, Hosingen and Monnerich in the Pagus Wabrensis, in Sarreburg, Berncastel and Roussy in the Pagus Mosellanus", was looking for a location for a castle able to withstand any onslaught which would serve as a central point for his holdings. After failing to obtain a site near the Abbey of Stavelot, now in the Belgian province of Liège, he approached the Abbot of St Maximin's for the purchase of the property high up on the Bock cliff above the Alzette River, described as a "castle by name Lucilinburhuc" (castellum quod dicitur Lucilinburhuc). It therefore seems as if there was already a castle on the site before Siegfried became interested in it and that it was not Siegfried who called it Lucilinburhuc. After the consent of Emperor Otto I had been obtained, the deed was signed by Viker, Abbot of St Maximin's, on 7 April 963. Siegfried acquired the site in exchange for some of his properties at Feulen.

Over the centuries, Siegfried's fortified castle on the Bock was considerably enlarged and protected with additional walls and defences. In 987, the castle chapel was built at the nearby Fish Market. Today's St Michael's Church stands on the same site.  Under Conrad I, the castle became the residence of the Counts of Luxembourg. It was damaged, destroyed, captured and rebuilt on several occasions as the Burgundians (1473), the Habsburgs (1477), and the Spaniards (1555) attacked and took the fortress.As time passed, the fortifications needed to be adapted to new methods of war based on increasingly strong firepower. During the 1640s under the Spaniards, the Swiss engineer Isaac von Treybach significantly reworked the defences. The Bock was also strengthened with three forts, the Large Bock, Middle Bock and Small Bock (from west to east), separated from each other by cuts in the rock and linked by bridges. As a result, little remained of the medieval castle.A little later in 1684, on behalf of Louis XIV, Vauban succeeded in capturing the city of Luxembourg during a month-long siege under which the Bock fortifications were completely flattened. Thereafter Vauban, perhaps the most competent fortification engineer of his day, undertook major additions to the defences, realizing that underground passages and chambers were just as important as the surface installations. The Large Bock, connected to the old town by the Pont du Château, was further reinforced. Enclosed by a wall 12 m (39 ft) high, it was the major component of the new fortress.

In addition to these structures, the Bock also included a system of casemates which originated in the cellars of the medieval castle. In 1744, during the Austrian period, these underground passages were considerably enlarged by General Neipperg. The main passage. which still remains, is 110 m long and up to 7 m wide. Branches leading off on either side were equipped with no less than 25 cannon slots, 12 to the north and 13 to the south, offering considerable firepower. In the event of war, the Bock casemates, covering an area of 1,100 m2, could be used as barracks for several hundred soldiers. Water was supplied from a well 47 m deep.Thanks to its defences, in 1794 during the French Revolutionary Wars, the city held out against a French siege for seven months. When the garrison finally surrendered, the walls were still unbreached. This led the French politician and engineer Lazare Carnot to call the Luxembourg fortress "the best in the world, apart from Gibraltar". As a result, it has often been called the Gibraltar of the North.
The fortifications were finally demolished under the terms of the Treaty of London in 1867. The demolition took 16 years and cost the enormous sum of 1.5 million gold francs.


== Pont du château ==

The two-storey bridge connecting the Bock to the old town was an important component of the fortifications. Technically, it is a rather curious structure. Built in 1735 by the Austrians, it provides no less than four ways of crossing between the cliffs: the road over the top, a passage by way of the four upper arches, a spiral staircase up through the main arch and a tunnel under the road at the bottom.


== Famous visitors ==
Over the years, the Bock casemates have received several famous visitors. These include:

Emperor Joseph II of Austria (1781);
Napoleon Bonaparte (1804);
Prince Henry of the Netherlands (1868);
Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg (1936);
Grand Duke Henri of Luxembourg and his wife Grand Duchess Maria Teresa (2000).


== The legend of Melusina ==
There have reportedly been people that have seen Melusine in the waters nearby.


== See also ==

History of Luxembourg

The tunnels are very expansive and go on for quite a bit!

Bring comfortable shoes and be ready to get comfortable with low lighting.

A real beautiful historic sight, Unique place. This World Heritage site was very very impressive! Nicely organized, This is priceless to see. Peace and Nature with great ancient architectural significance,  definitely worth a visit.

Quite interesting, but hard to know where to go. We almost missed a staircase leading to a whole extra floor and saw at least one other couple standing around wondering where to go (we showed them to the staircase). All in we saw everything in about half an hour, which seemed quite quick, wonder if we missed anything.

Very impressive historical place

Pro tip: If you are in Luxembourg city on a rainy day, then visiting the caves would probably be the best thing you could do!

I was here on (19.10.19) with my mum and a friend and the caves which is an UNESCO heritage site is surely the …

Very nice! Didn’t had time to go inside, but the view already was worth to go there. We will definitely come again an check the city and the casematten out again! We would love to discover it, i wonder how much of the suppose to exist and left 17km of underground is possible to access ? I love to find out ;)

Fine but don't expect anything magical. You pay €7 euros to walk around underground for as long as you want but that is it really. There's no info or anything else to look at. There are some lookout points where you can see nice views, but it's just similar looking corridors. I spent about 30 mins down there.

The casements were boring and the information boards were not in English making it a waste of time to visit.
I would suggest paying the extra and joining a guided tour as these are provided in English if you wanted to visit this world heritage site.
Personally I would suggest spending the time visiting other areas of the city.
Very beautiful place 😍

Not the first time we have been here but it’s been 10 years. It hasn’t changed. Great time exploring the tunnels. Kids had fun and it was a relief on a hot day to be inside and cool. Get a map though. Not hard to get lost but to know u went everywhere. It’s a walk so wear comfortable shoes and watch ur step
Luxembourg is very beautiful city. I have amazing time there

Lovely place, shame it's not open in integraty. It's meant to be over 20 km of corridors, but you can only visit 1km.
Lovely views of Luxembourg and interesting to imagine how it could've been used as shelter
Good place to spend an hour.. Mostly walk around to different balconies and few narrow stairs and closed areas. Careful not to get lost.

You need to visit this amazing historic place. Here you will find something which is really carved in stone ;-). In hot summer, even a good place to calm down. Recommendation: Could be an option to buy the Luxembourg card at the Tourist information. Entry fee, public transport and other attractions are included.

While driving back to Germany from Brussels, I decided to take a pit stop in Luxembourg for lunch.  With only a couple hours to spend in town before getting back on the road I decided to take a tour of the Casements.  This is a great …
Nicely organized, definitely worth a visit. Nice walking inside the fortifications. Some spots with nice view but nothing extraordinary.
Thoroughly enjoyed our walk around all of Luxembourg City including the casements and municipal park. One of the nicest, cleanest cities in our entire European trip

Fun but could have more history, more explanations, something... This way it is just a nice walk inside a mountain, when it could be a full historical experience
Interesting place and nice view over the city... It is mandatory to visit this place if you are in Luxembourg...Enjoy it! 😊
A real beautiful historic sight. This is priceless to see. Visit, close your eyes and imagine what life was like.

Perhaps the most historical place of Luxembourg.
(If you don't have GPS there is not to much signals saying "Casemates du Bock".
This place is the rest of the fortification that sorrounded the old village of Luxembourg.
Every view point has …

It is really full with nice places wben that it was raining

It was an amazing experience and worth the visit. We even got the coin souvenir and it was so pretty and shiny. I definitely recommend this to visit if you are in luxembourg because this is the gateway to learn more about their past and …

Great price. The tunnels are stunning, be careful if you are tall though as you'll easily hit your head!

Incredible views too!

Not too pricey with only 7 euros for entrance and the tunnels are amazing to walk through (and nice and cold on a hot day). The only thing I missed was some more information (English would be a great addition). Also the lighting in some places was not great.
Beautiful. They are as if they are from a fairytale.

Such a beautiful place! The view is just like a fairy tail world. The cute houses with grey blue roof, the river carries the romantic atmosphere. In spring all the flowers are blooming, which bring bright colors to this place. Love it!

This is an interesting place to walk through. With the Luxembourg card it was free but if we had paid the regular entrance fee, which think is $15EU I would have been very disappointed. Feel they could do a better job with signage so you can easily make your way around. You just kind of wander around without knowing where to go next.

it is UNESCO heritage of 17 k.m. long tunnel with an amazing view. The ticket was 7 EUR per person for the tunnels. It is not wheelchair or pram friendly.The tunnels had interesting spots inside about where people hid themselves. They can …

It was cool, but very repetitive. We went down a staircase that brought us down, around, across, and right back up on the other side of the wall we went down. Also a spot for couples to find private corners to make out in. Views were decent, but you can see the same things without paying from above.

I really recommend visiting the Casemates because it's a very nice experience. The panoramic views are amazing. The tunnels are illuminated and very easy to use. It's safe also for visiting with kids. They don't give you a map for the …

Even without paying the entrance fee and going inside the walls, there is a lot to see just by walking around the ramparts and looking at the plaques. The info is in French  and German, though. Amazing views of the Grund and other ancient parts of the city and its bridges.

Nice visit, but it's difficult to navigate all the sections because there aren't clear signs and direction arrows. You'd expect it to be better organized and maintained for the €7 entrance fee they're charging.
One of most interesting places in Luxembourg, to visit. Many caves and long tunnels drilled in bare rock. Very nice views from inside.
An interesting place to see if you are visiting Luxembourg. I still go there once in a while at night to just sit and enjoy the view of the old town

A nice place to visit! It doesn’t look so bug from outside, but its totally a surprise inside! The views are pretty cool from inside! Specially the narrow staircases from the olden days are a bit adventurous!

Very interesting! It was a bit busy, so sometimes we had to wait to look at a view or something. You might consider doing the guided tour, there isn't much information in the Kazematten if you walk trough yourself.
Excellent experience with kids, to see the history of the cliffs and castle, but to be able to explore, wander around and see the city from a different view.
Nice and cool place to explore. Interesting part of the city's history.  Be sure to pick up the brochure by the ticket booth if you want information about each part of the casemates.
Peace, Calmness and Nature with great ancient architectural significance.  Lovely place to visit

I would love to give this place the full five stars that it deserves, but it is under construction, so if someone is planning a trip mainly to see this attraction they should consider this.

A good deal of the structure is not accessible …
It's an amazing piece of history, I would recommend trying the guided tour in order to have a better experience

The price of 7 euro is too expensive for what you get in return. The lack of signs makes it difficult to find your way through the tunnels and understand the history of the place. The whole sight can be visited in about 30 minutes. If you have seen castles before, it is not really worth visiting.
I recommend that you get a ticket and visit the undergrounds. This is a three-dimensional maze made in a Mountain. Fun experience!

There are nice views from balconies and cannon holes. The place is badly signed though so we had to circle back a few times. Not much description either.
On the plus side, I enjoyed colourful lights installed in the caves.

One of nicest spots to go for a drink near the palace and with nice preserved old town style. You will also find a free museum nearby, an amazing view to grund. Check also the caves during spring or summer.

You have to pay to go inside and it’s a tad overpriced. The passages might be fun for kids to explore but otherwise it’s a bit cramped and repetitive. You can get the idea from the outside without going on. That’s where the great views are anyway.
One more heritage place... What mesmerizes is the restoration, preservation of the age old structures.... Excellent efforts by Luxembourg government and UNICEF
A sneak peak literally down the history of this beautiful place called Luxembourg
Incredible views within and toward outside. Exhausting to walk but totally worth it. I would go again.
Unique place, even more beautiful by night and when it snows

Great place to visit. But lot to walk if you want to enjoy the beauty.

Really nice place to explore the history of Luxembourg. The entrance fee is 7e per adult and cash only. I had to go to ATM and the closest one is quite an uphill walk away so be sure not to do the same mistake.

You can discover some cool caves, kind of a mini maze too ! Should check out if interested in history of the place. Also offers some cool views of city ! The whole trip only takes 30mins inside caves.

Interesting tunnels for a reasonable price. Not recommended if you have claustrophobia or if you aren't very mobile because there is a tight spiral staircase, dark areas with uneven ground and thing corridors. 
Good views of the city from …

I only had a day in Luxembourg.  This is an easy walk from the train station and was a great experience.  Note- need cash for entry.

The views from going under here are very similar to the views from the top of the museum which is free. Paid zero as had Luxembourg card but would have been disappointed if I'd paid 7 euros for a small exhibit and entrance to dungeon with windows out showing the same 2 view points.
A bit pricy,  not much to see minus the view.
Nice walk across the Wenzel path led us besides these huge defensive structures. Highly recommended, but beware the steep climbs.
Great place to wander and explore! Not too crowded (we got there pretty early). Great for all ages, but be ready to walk and climb up and down stairs.

This site offers amazing views, a must see when in Luxembourg City. The casemates aren't open all the time, but there's plenty to see even when closed. The river valley is beautiful with flowering trees, an open vista and the classic architecture. It's also an easy walk from the city center.

It is the first underground tunnels built in 1644, in the era of the Spanish domination.40 years later they were enlarged by the French military, and in the eighteenth century by the Austrians. It was great to know more information.

Must visit at Luxembourg.

Interesting enough place to visit and see.  Not a lot of information is given about it though.  I learned more about it from Google and Wikipedia.

Amazing history. Lots to explore. Be prepared for many stairs, cool temperatures, and some very narrow passageways. Some incredible views of the city below from the archways of the labyrinth. Definitely worth the bit of cardio.

Beautiful old walls and fortress, it's only been open to the public since the 1930's and had been used in WWll as a bomb shelter for up to 35'000 people! This capital is one of my favourite cities in Europe! Absolutely stunning, like you are walking around in a storybook...
Awesome place to explore in Luxembourg. Works you legs out for a good sit down dinner!
Really worth it! .. But not if you are claustrophobic
Quite a fun time with the family. Great views outside and cool caverns inside. Put it on your list.
Very interesting, affordable and great views of the city. Lots of stairs however so just a heads up. Worth doing for sure.
Must visit when in Luxembourg. WWII bunkers
Like taking a trip back in time! Enjoyed walking through it, amazing views, history is all around you here:)
It was really fun and bit confused. But we should have stamina to walk around the cave! It was like a puzzle.
Super cool area, I would recommend just visiting and exploring all the free areas. Very nice, so no need to pay
Super awesome, enjoyed my cigar looking at historical yet modern view... booked  guided tour the next day
7 euros per person to enter but totally worth it. Really unique experience to wander around the casemates and you get a lot of nice views of the city too.
Beautiful place.. underground ruins are really amazing to visit.. feels like a maze.. a must visit ofcorse for anyone visiting Luxembourg City.
Stunning vistas of the city below from the high medieval walls. I really enjoyed strolling around that beautiful part of town which has a lot of history and scenic beauty. Not to be missed!
Really nice! Definitely should walk around and visit this place in Luxemberg!

Very impressive to see and experience. The history of how the people defended luxembourg in the past is very interesting. The tour guide was a bit boring but a very nice and wonderful man. The people of luxembourg are very proud of their heritage and culture.

We had not really planned to visit Luxembourg, but are very glad we did. Lots to see and do, very prosperous, just shows what low tax does for your economy. Some wonderful public spaces and facilities.

We took out two girls (3 & 5 years old) into the caves. They loved it the excitement of exploring what’s next or down the steep spiral staircases was a great adventure.

Old castle of Luxembourg . Nice and interesting experience through the casemates and tunnels .
I advise to take the guided tour (even as a Luxembourger, I learned plenty of stuff) !

Interesting and quite impressive, there isn't much to see diversity wise.
Lots of nice views, very informative and a nice play to go to get away from the heat on a sunny day.

Good view but thats all, a bit boring to be honest
Lots of climbing up and down stairs. Great views. Do it if you have time and nothing else to do.
Very beautiful views, nice historic spot. Adult tickets cost 7 euros. Very recommendable!

The highlight maybe of my trip in Luxembourg!Amazing view down to the valley.You relax with the serendipity caused from the huge amount of green!You can get a lot of photos from above and after that enjoy a walk down to the Petrusse valley crossing short bridges,waterfalls and beautiful parks!Don't miss it!
Must see if you visit Luxembourg. Interesting to explore
So unique. I have never seen such a place like this.  It's a must place to see if in Luxembourg

The Bock Casemates are more than a kilometer in length, and the most fulfilled cave is 110m x 7m. This fantastic complex of caves (which one day was 23 km long) made Luxembourg one day known as Gibraltar in the north.

Lovely place to explore the Casemates. The kids loved going through the various caverns, but there are lots of stairs!

We probably covered it all in about 1hr, though as we had small children, we weren't able to go on a guided tour which I am sure would take longer.
Lots of history to explore here. We had a guide for a couple of hours and well worth it.
Was interesting but a lack of signage will frustrate how you get through it.
Wanderful country we took bus tour from bruxell in Belgium.. To many wanderful areas.

Interesting place to visit who like history. They are made in 17th century. It is a labyrinth in the rock what seems like was constructed as a shelter in case of a war.
It coasts 7€ for adults to visit

Good price at €7 to enter. It is literally a short stroll under Luxembourg in an area dug out in the 17th century to house canons. Other than that it's a rock face with viewing points. Lasts about 20 minutes.
Very cool!  Definitely recommended.

If Luxembourg becomes too hot for your liking, you can take refuge in these cold passageways for the generous price of 7€. Otherwise just a couple of scenic cave balconies. Three stars, one extra for the temperature.
Interesting place to walk around. Make sure you get a brochure from the front because there are no other information markers throughout. The place is also cash only.
very interesting

This place is amazing and I am impressed by the way it has been looked after, after so many years.

I was dissapointed to see that there weren't any English translations as with this I would have rated the visit 🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟
It really  needs more explanation pósters and better lights. Luxembourg landmark, do not miss a visit
Amazing landscape. Great place for hiking.Lots of places to discover. Lots of parking lot around (not free)
Interesting old fortress to explore well worth the 7euro. Has good views of the surrounding area.
This place offers some great insight on the start of Luxembourg. Also a nice place for plane spotting. Look out for the majestic 747s and 777s ;)
Great pice of Luxembourg history. Breathtaking views on old town.
The historical point that is important for both eastern and Western European. Hence the castle was destructed in world war and everyone hope to capture this part as the defensive spot
Probably it the best POI in Luxembourg, but I can't say, that casemats are amazing.
7 EUR entrance fee - relatively cheap activity for Luxembourg
Casemates of Bock in Luxemburg city, very nice and restaurated. You may combine with a lovely trip around the city center (old city) and the surroundings of Neumünster

One of my favorite things about this city. Full of history and has beautiful views over the valley. I recommend taking the guided tour that happens in the spring till autumn.
Historic fort for dating back to 965. Great views
Wonderful place that takes you back several hundred years in history.
If you like wandering around old tunnels this place is perfect. The tour is self guided so you're free to explore every nook and cranny as you please. Beautiful views of the city from every window.

No option for zero stars. Because they wouldn't let me in. I walk with sticks and their rule is disabled people with walking aids are not allowed. I am perfectly able to navigate uneven surfaces and steep stairs but they would not leave it up to me. I will complain and hope they change the discriminatory policy.

Lovely historical sight. When we visited there was a jazz band playing inside and it was amazing. Ensure you have a map when walking through the site as one area is a dead end and requires a long walk back.
Interesting place to visit, quite spacious with many ins and outs to discover

Our entry was included with the Luxembourg card, but if you pay it is well worth the money as we spent such a long time seeing almost everything (one section was closed). Make sure to pick up a map/guidebook at the front desk as there is no information as you go round. Well worth a visit!
Amazing and breathtaking view! You can't leave the city without visit it. Check availability during the winter time.
Nice historical place but need some maintenance

The Casemates are a super cool place to visit, though it would likely be better in the summer when more of it is open. Great views of the city and river at any time though all of which are freely accessible.
Awesome place to visit.great way to experience history... beautiful maintained and givee a out of world experience...
Insane. So old so cool best thing we saw on our 20 day trip

Probably the main attraction in the city, often called 'balcony of Europe'! It's a beautiful place to go to. You can walk through the trails and  centuries old tunnels. There are two lifts operating nearby, one of them with stunning view! …

text.wiki:
Notre-Dame Cathedral (Luxembourgish: Kathedral Notre-Dame, French: Cathédrale Notre-Dame, German: Kathedrale unserer lieben Frau) is the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Luxembourg City, in southern Luxembourg. It was originally a Jesuit church, and its cornerstone was laid in 1613. It is the only cathedral in Luxembourg.
The church is a noteworthy example of late gothic architecture; however, it also has many Renaissance elements and adornments. At the end of the 18th century, the church received the miraculous image of the Maria Consolatrix Afflictorum, the patron saint of both the city and the nation. 
Around 50 years later, the church was consecrated as the Church of Our Lady and in 1870, it was elevated by Pope Pius IX to the Cathedral of Notre-Dame.
At the cemetery of the cathedral is the National Monument to the Resistance and to the Deportation. The centerpiece of the monument is the famous bronze monument by the 20th century Luxembourgish sculptor Lucien Wercollier called The Political Prisoner.
The cathedral was expanded and enlarged from 1935 to 1938.


== History ==
Jesuits from Belgium, which like Luxembourg belonged to the Spanish Netherlands at the time, opened a college in Luxembourg city in 1603, where the majority of young Luxembourgers were taught until 1773. The first stone of the church was laid on 7 May 1613, under Father François Aldenard. The constructor of the building was Ulrich Job, from Lucerne. Under him, the decoration of the columns also took place. The Jesuit church was consecrated and dedicated to the Immaculate Conception on 17 October 1621 by auxiliary bishop Georg von Helfenstein.
Artistically, it was above all the German sculptor Daniel Muller (died 1623) from Freiberg (Saxony) who contributed to the appearance of the church, his work including the organ tribune. The decorations in alabaster, a favourite material of Dutch Renaissance sculptors, represent early Baroque angels, who play music between leaves and floral decorations.
After the Jesuits had left the city in 1773, Empress Maria Theresa of Austria gifted the church to the City of Luxembourg in 1778, and it became the new parish church under the name "Saint Nicolas et Sainte Thérèse". This was convenient, as at the time the old parish church, the church of St. Nicholas on the Krautmaart was small and decrepit, and was demolished in 1779. For this reason, a statue of St. Nicholas stands over the cathedral entrance in Rue Notre-Dame.
It received the name "Notre-Dame" on 31 March 1848 under the apostolic vicar Jean-Théodore Laurent. His successor, Nicolas Adames, had the Baroque interior refurbished from 1854 in a neo-Gothic style. When Luxembourg was elevated to a bishopric by Pope Pius IX on 27 June 1870, the Notre-Dame Church became Notre-Dame Cathedral.


== Architecture ==
Though a noteworthy example of late gothic architecture, the cathedral has many Renaissance elements and adornments.


=== 20th century enlargement ===
From 1935 to 1938 the cathedral was enlarged and expanded. This enlargement, which influence the silhouette of the fortress city of Luxembourg, went ahead according to plans by and under the supervision of the Luxembourgish architect Hubert Schumacher. The expanded area, which connects to the two choir bays of 1613–1621, characterises the image of the former Jesuit church both due to its spaciousness and through the architectural unity. The rebuilding of the exterior architecture on the Gothic-style cathedral presented a challenge, since the goal was to harmoniously integrate the church with the surrounding buildings, such as the former Athénée building from the 17th century, the national library, the old church of St. Maximin (1751) (now the Foreign Ministry), as well as the old residential houses.


=== Towers ===
The cathedral has three towers: the west tower, which was the tower of the Jesuit church and which contains the bells, the east tower, and the central tower, which stands over the transept.
When the cathedral was enlarged in 1935–1938, the east and central towers were added. The central tower, which is only a third of the height of the other towers, consists of a wide, pyramid-shaped base and a narrow peak covered with copper. The roof itself is carried by a steel frame, consisting of two PN20 beams from ARBED-Belval.
On Good Friday, 5 April 1985, around mid-day, work on the roof caused the west tower to catch fire. The church bells, i.e. the Virgin Mary bell, the Willibrord bell, the Peter bell, and the Cunigunde bell, were destroyed in the fire. When the tower collapsed, the roof of the central aisle was also partly damaged. It took until 17 October 1985 for the tower to be repaired.


== Burials in the crypt ==
The crypt of the cathedral contains the remains of Grand Dukes and Grand Duchesses of Luxembourg. The following people are interred here:

Marie-Adélaïde I, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg (1894–1924)
Marie Anne, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg, born Infanta of Portugal (1861–1942) – Consort of William IV
Felix, Prince Consort of Luxembourg, born Prince of Bourbon-Parma (1893–1970) – Consort of Charlotte I
Prince Charles (1927–1977)
Charlotte I, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg (1896–1985)
Joséphine Charlotte, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg, born Princess of Belgium (1927–2005) – Consort of Jean I
Jean I, Grand Duke of Luxembourg (1921-2019)


== See also ==
Roman Catholic Marian churches
List of Archbishops of Luxembourg


== References ==
The information in this article is based on a translation of its German equivalent.

A quiet, beautiful, and grand Cathedral. It is a must see while in the city and it will not disappoint. Not much else to say!
Beautiful church, the workmanship is unreal. Stop and light a candle. Would h Recommend seeing it.the location is great right in the city center

This cathedral is not the one of Victor Hugo ' s Hunchback of Note Dame (located in France)but it is still very impressive. The stained glass windows inside are very impressive and if you visit in the correct sunlight,this nice quiet building is aglow with the colour from them.

Notre Dame is one of my favorite sites in Paris. There is so much to see inside, and it's beautiful and peaceful. The stained glass is amazing, and we loved spending time in there. I could literally stay in there for hours. Even though the line was rather long to get inside,
Someone needs to take the time to clean up the area to allow tourists to enjoy. It is not a safe zone at dusk.

This was a beautiful Cathedral, with very impressive stained glass and beautiful woodwork around the confessional booths. The Blessed Sacrament chapel was moving and there was a good selection from the Cathedral shop at the rear.
Not a cathedral to spend for a long time but if you happen to pass by, take time to visit this beautiful cathedral and check out the crypt.
This is a very nice place for a short visit. Entry is free. The crypt appears to only be open in the mornings.
I like visiting cathedrals and this one was very good. No charge to go in and look round. And loved the downstairs section as well. Worth a look if into cathedrals.
Worth a visit, wonderful stained glass windows and a peaceful space. Make sure you also visit the crypt which is decidedly cooler on hot days.
Always great to take a pew, relax & take in the smell & beautiful windows . We went in on a Sunday during a service, so a back seat, kept quite and enjoyed the hymns.
Looks as other reviews of pictures. Decent cathedral. Has to be one of the stops even if you’re not into them.
This church is amazing and with so much history. The stain glass is just beautiful and really worth a visit.
Tradional church in city center . Pay Parking across the street . Nice to stop in andsee if your also visitng the palace which is 5 minutes away by foot.
A wonderful monument to 13 Century architecture and masonry. As part of a your including many wonderful churches and cathedrals this was last and certainly far from least.
A very big cathedral built in baroque architecture , but also with Gothic elements . First built in 1613 . Serves as a Roman Catholic Church . In the southern part of Luxembourg.
Very nice stop to take some pictures and visit. One of the many great sights worth seeing here in the city
It is free to enter and worth a visit to see the beautiful stained glass window. Great view of over the river from the outside too
Just dropped by on our foot tour. Impressive cathedral, but just one of many. Ok to take a visit. But nothing more.

This Cathedral looks great from the outside and the gargoyle fountain head in the ground are worth a look. However inside the cathedral is fairly lackluster unless you are a pipe organ enthusiast. Worth 15-30 min if your day.
Nice cathedral with lovely stained glass windows. Mass for the national holiday was on when we visited so couldn’t explore too much!
Don’t miss the tomb of the blind king in the lower church. The church is great and worth the visit. The windows are lovely

I love touring churches but this one is better from the outside than the inside. We stopped in during a church service and it was nice, just not astounding. Swing by, but your pics can be accomplished from the outside.
Gorgeous cathedral and free to get in which was a lovely surprise. Beautiful stain glass windows and candle display, we lit one.

Lovely looking building from the front and once inside there are some impressive stained glass windows and architecture to admire. There was an organ demonstration going on whilst we were there for people to enjoy. If you arrive by the back entrance then you could easily miss

Who would like to spend the day in a church? and not a very beautiful one to boot? Go somewhere else, like the Museum of Modern Art or Abbaye Neumunster in Grund, or stroll along the streets of the city centre and visit the Palace.
We didnt intended on going here but we stumble on it while trying to find our restaurant. This is a must see very beautiful on the inside. Make sure to also go downstairs also.
Notre Dame Cathedral is a must- see while in Luxembourg. The architecture and windows are so beautiful and it's something worth the effort to get to see.
Beautiful church and crypt - lovely stone work. We were fortunate to visit as mass was beginning so we heard the lovely Ave Maria too

I don’t really know why.... But I would really expect something better! They had many rooms closed and to some others you need tickets! But you pay more that you should.... Guys after all it is a Cathedral!

Beautiful church in prime area of Luxembourg. Beautiful stained glass. Grand but not overdone. Luxembourg is very clean and pedestrian friendly although so many tour buses. Not a lot to see other than the cathedral but worth the trip.

If possible check out the opening & service times before going, that way it's easier to plot it into a day's itinerary. You can also allow enough time either for service & communion or just reflection & prayer time as required.
We visited the Catherdral as part of our walking tour (booked at the tourism centre). The visit with a guide was good as unique local features and history were explained.
We went several times during our stay, the stained glass windows are amazing. We were lucky enough to listen to a free organ concert too, it's a must to see if visiting the city.

The Notre Dame Cathedral in Luxembourg is definitely worth a visit. It's quite enormous on the inside, with the stained glass paintings and the ornate chandeliers creating a spectacular effect. You can also visit the crypt and there are some stalls inside selling books.
This is a gorgeous building, very peaceful and open to all. Worth a visit if you're in the area. At the side entrance there is an interesting wall explaining it's history.

This cathedral is beautiful and pairs an impressive size and scale, with a stunning simplicity and superb stained glass windows. The crypt too is well worth the visit which, in contrast to many darker ones, feels light and bright, with the beautiful inner space of shiny marble.
Magnificent building in central Luxembourg city and really well taken care of. And very important, this catholic church is entirely free to visit, which is always a plus!
Step inside and you will be amazed how big it is. From outside it doesn't look so spacious. The glass is masterpeace!
Gothic building, with the most famous in Paris just share the name and the presence of two bell towers. Huge crypt, a nit more modern and quite full of light.

Having visited already a few cathedrals before, this one did not let down taking into consideration that it's located in a small country. It is not huge, but the architecture is eye-catching. Free entrance is certainly a plus.
Nice cathedral in the city center. Impressive architecture and nice on the inside. However, honestly, if you only have limited time in Luxembourg, I wouldn't go out of my way to visit it.
Notre Dame Cathedral is beautiful.In Lux is in the city centre.The archirecture is inside awesome,the oldest cathedral,quite big with pretty colourful windows.
We were pleasantly surprised at how lovely this cathedral is, and spent a relaxing afternoon wandering about studying the beautiful windows and other artwork.

I had the opportunity to take in a Pontificate Mass where the Archbishop of Krakow was the celebrant. It was a very formal occasion, and it appeared that the Grand Duke of Luxembourg was in attendance. I was pleased to see that the service was overflowing. A joyous experience it

...to pray, light a candle and take a look to the gothic architecture and the painted glases. It is very close to the city centre (Luxemburg is, after all, a small city) so you cannot miss it. Free entrance.

Beautiful historical Cathedral! Gothic architecture, beautiful alter, and stain glass windows A must stop if in the Luxembourg City area. A brief history with photographs of John Paul was in the rear of the church which was fascinating and enlightening.

Luxembourg city is very quiet, green and vibrant city. One side you can see modern building and other side you can see old fort with old buildings. One moment you are in concrete jungle and other moment you are in real jungle. Nitre Dame cathedral which is at the city center is
Went to Sunday mass at the Notre Dame Cathedral! Absolutely beautiful Cathedrale. Even if one is not a Catholic, a visit to this Cathedral is a must.

This is long past the time when each kingdom competed with the next on who could build the tallest. It is built along the same lines as 13th century cathedrals but the engineering had evolved so they could do more. The interior is lighter looking than older works. Worth seeing.

It is a beautiful church, you would notice it even you have not crossed the bridge to the city centre. The cathedral is not so big compared with other cathedrals. The internal paintings and statues are beautiful. It is worthy to visit if the guest is going to Luxembourg. I

Hell-O everyone Just come back from Luxembourg so lets begin Notre Dame Cathedral is situated 2 min walk from city center. The name is the same as Paris one but different. Its a roman Catholic Church build in 1613 Very nice and worth it to visit
This is a must see venue in the city - it is a beautifully kept building with a history which reflects is grandeur.
Wonderful windows. Ornate columns. Really restful because people are so respectful. lovely frescoes and tapestries.

The outside of the building looks great. very nicely build. Inside is very quite peaceful;; with lovely stained windows you can light candles inside. The only off putting was the old lady allowed to sit at the door with a begging bowl.

The outside of the church is very nice, but inside, apart from the structure and the very gorgeous stained glass windows, doesn’t offer much. The cathedral in Trier is much more elaborate and the stonework and statues are amazing. If you like churches it’s definitely worth a
We visited the notre dame cathedral in Luxembourg and we really aprecited it! Nice architecture and pretty quiet! We recommend it
Very nice Cathédrale in the centre of Luxembourg city. You have to wear modest clothing in order to get inside.

A beautiful cathedral in the heart of Luxembourg... It is called Notre Dame... It is beautiful from outside and inside... You can pray peacefully in a quiet environment... It looks very old... Mosaic is in many areas on the walls... You can light a small candle for 0.50 euros...

There is plenty of history, art, and explanations in English. The life of Jesus is illustrated on the interior archway. Each confessional has unique wood carving. Remember this is an active church with daily services and parishioners praying during the day. Do not miss the

Well what a great visit. Access to the cathedral is free, only donate for lighting a candle. Beautiful architecture and ambiance. Well worth a visit if you are visiting the city. This among the many other sights to see is well worth it. Has some beautiful stained glass windows.
Something to look at! Big church, very pretty. It’s right at the edge of the cry centre so very easy to get too!

It is simple but beautiful both outside and inside. It is full of history - there is even a written account of the history of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg for history buffs. The crypt is the resting place of the royal family and archbishops.
Enough said this place is a must visit whilst you are in Luxeembourg. Free entry to this wonderful Cathedral.
Serenely beautiful place of worship. Marvellous stained glass windows and gothic artitecture. It's a must see.

Okay, it's not the Notre Dame of Paris, but it is a beautiful building. It was originally a Jesuit church, the foundation stone of which was laid in 1613. It is a remarkable example of late Gothic style, revealing various components & ornaments inspired by Renaissance style.

The cathedral is localized in the central part of the city of Luxembourg and is definitely worth to spend a few mins to step in. Maybe the cathedral doesn’t look as spectacular as Norte dame in Paris or Marian church in Cracow, as it’s much smaller etc. however the walls inside

As a step while walking along the Valley of the Petrusse River, I make a short stop in the Notre Dame Cathedral during a free organ concert. Half an hour calm and respectful moment before discovering more of the Upper City of Luxembourg.
Definitely worth a look - stain glass windows are very pretty. Also go down the steps to the crypt for other good photo opportunities.

Doesn’t match its name sake in either Paris or Montreal, but a decent cathedral nonetheless The highlight would have to be the stained glass windows surrounding the altar Other than that, it’s another place of worship

This church qualifies as a cathedral only because there is an archbishop in Luxembourg ! Otherwise this would just be a (nice, big) church , of lesser interest ! Its architecture can in no way be compared to the great cathedrals in France or England...

This cathedral was very light inside for such a large church. I don't know what year it was built, but it definitely feels modern. Still it was beautiful inside. We happened to visit during a mid-day service and got to hear the organ and cantor. The sound was impressive.
Popped into the Cathedral on a rainy day. Serene atmosphere beautiful stained glass. There is nothing particularly spectacular to mention, it is a beautiful little cathedral.
Oh my God this vitrail!!!! Every time I pass by this place I go inside for a few seconds just to see the vitrail! It's magical!

Perhaps the cathedral was heavily damaged during WWII, but I unfortunately would have to admit that I was rather disappointed, the cathedral was very plain and didn't feel quite coherent. The location is somewhat sad too, being tucked away between bigger more modern buildings.

Do not expect too much ; one of these secondary belonging formely to a Benedictine cloister has become the cathedral of Luxembourg and a few people had in middle ages the idea to initiate a Maria worshipping and many Luxembourgers pilgrates there around Easter times. In these

Grand impressive building , mixture of internal design, showing how extension melts into original build Various crafts beautifully enchanted the building ,stained glass, mosaic , tapestry A must see on any visit to this city

After going to the Christmas market next to the church we come inside and we see all the nice work done from all over the world and each country have there own ideas to make the best of the Christmas holidays season decoration and represent their country. It’s a old and nice
Very beautiful old Cathedral with nice vitraux, paintings, peaceful atmosphere a most visit in Luxembourg city.
Visiting the city, it was snowing, so beautiful.. The architecture is really cool, I really love the center of the city

Beautiful 16th century mix of gothic and renaissance architecture. The crypt of the Cathedral contains the remains of members of the Grand-Ducal family You definitely will will feel the serenity inside.
This is mixture of old with a new extension built in the 1930's. It has lots of stained glass windows.
Unassuming from the outside, although beautiful, once inside the sun streaming through the stunning stained glass and the calm atmosphere meant it was a very pleasant visit
A beautiful cathedral with lots of history associated with it! Our tour guide spoke to us about the royal family and their historic relationship with the church which was really interesting
We were amazed with how beautiful the stained glass windows were Complete tranquility downstairs and amazed by what appeared to be a serious security absence
Notre Dame Cathedral is quite pretty and just a short walk from the centre of Luxembourg. Worth a visit.

Luxembourg City is one of the most beautiful European capitals. The cathedral is in the center of the historic center, next to the tourist office. There is parking available under the complex. The church is very beautiful but simple and elegant. Don’t expect extravagant, soaring
Very similar to the “original”. Beautiful building, nice to sit in for a short time to make some thinking.
He outside is quite plane as cathedrals go bit the stained glass windows and stone work is amazing!! Little gem!
I sang for the Sunday Mass with my chamber choir from the balcony in this beautiful cathedral. The acoustics were very good and the surroundings are beautiful.

this is a place worth visiting.it has a more modern feel about it than many other cathedrals i've been to.it has many interesting things to see like the stained glass window,the organ etc,but what i found quite interesting was the crypt.you have to look carefully for the stairs

Beautiful vitro excellent tapisseries ,light candles ,the statue of the Holy Mary and 2 musical organs compose this beautiful scenery of relaxing your soul even if you don’t believe .A must in Luxembourg!

Beautiful outside but truly amazing on the inside. We went there twice during our 2 day stay, supposedly outside the opening hours but it was open during lunch time and the evening, so try it at any hour. It's definitely worth the visit!

you should visit if u have time, interesting architecture and won't need to pay.you can spend some time here and some pix. located in the heart of the city. Interesting tapestries and very nice glass windows

We went in the church with our children, 3, 11 and 12 years. They were mesmerized by the details they could find inside. Very beautiful and peaceful. Are you in Luxembourg, is it a must to go and see.
A must see Cathedral, really beautiful inside and also outside. The entrance is free and you will be able to visit the inside and also the crypt.
Luxembourg is a nice place to walk around but to be honest there aren’t many world famous sights. However, the cathedral is probably one of its best and is definitely worth a visit if you are there.
Not the largest or most impressive church in Europe, but still worth the 15-20 minutes it takes to visit.

Cathedrals Notre Dame, or Our Lady of Luxembourg is gorgeous. It is more beautiful that Notre Dame in Paris. The tall stained glass windows behind the alter, the exquisitely carved stone on the columns and balconies especially in the back where the the organ is and the
This is only my second church on this trip but, it is kind of eating a box if chocolates. At first the chocolate is delicious but after awhile, it's just too much. Still, Note Dame is beautiful.

This is one of the most beautiful Notre Dame cathedral we have seen across Europe. Although it is not as big in size as the one in Paris, this cathedral has its own charm with an arch like section with paintings in the middle section of the church. It has a crypt as well,
This is a lovely cathedral but it is unlikely to take longer than 20-30 minutes to appreciate. The stained glass is fantastic, as is some of the baroque stonework around the organ loft.

This has got to be one of the most fascinating cathedrals we have visited in Europe. Take note at the back of the cathedral, on each side of the facade there is two small dragons, one of them is laying upside down on it's back. There must be a story behind it but we do not know
The cathedral is well worth a visit. Of course it`s not only about the spiritual aspect. There are some beautiful painted windows and other art work on display.
Quite busy, even in late September. A lovely feel to the building. Don't miss the crypt - it is marked, but not exactly signposted

Of the things to see in Luxembourg City, the cathedral has got to rank among the must-sees. It's truly beautiful. I happened to visit when an organ concert was being given, so it was lovely to hear the instrument. Beautiful space.
This is a lovely Cathedral with noteworthy stained glass features. In my opinion it is worth a visit, but we did not spend long here.

On a sunny day this very nice cathedral lightens up inside with beautiful colors, giving a special, serene atmosphere!
Quite nice cathedral, but nothing especially catching. Come around if you are walking by, but no special need unless you are looking for place for a quite prayer.
Unfortunately i didnt have time to pop in to see the cathedral fully. It is very easy to find and easily spotted. Its a lovely old church with beautiful old stained windows.
Lovely cathedral. I particularly liked the stained glass. Located near the city centre definitely worth a visit.

Not the most impressive cathedral in Europe, but a must stop in in your trip, gothic, nice stained glass, and access to the crypt free of charge. Fully functioning worship temple, consideration is advised if only sight seeing. I have seen larger churches and smaller cathedrals,
Beautiful old church , amazing history and stained glass windows. You can feel time slipping away just opening the doors and walking inside to it's majesty .
lovely cathedral, polite and knowledgeable staff on hand, free attraction that only takes a short time to see. right by most of the other attractions, so you do not have to go out of your way
Great building even for non christians - beautiful windows and an amazing church overall - worth a visit
We popped in for a quick look, free to enter which is nice as so many these days are not. Lovley stained glass window over the alter, and a nice cooling break from the hot sun
The cathedral has the most lovely windows and some impressive ceiling paintings. There are two periods reflected in the interior. Its worth a visit.
Very interesting place with history. Superb windows and well maintained. Some work ongoing actually inside.
If you come to visit Luxembourg this cathedral is absolutely with coming to visit. It's located in the city center, so after that there are lots of other places to walk around and see.
Very beautiful this place. Nice view. Good for a rainy or dry day. Good for a trip with little children.
Interesting place, lots of history, unfortunately we couldn't go on a guided tour ad it was fully booked 👍
Compared to the churches in Italy, this one is sober. Little woodwork, little statues, very nice and colorfull windows.
It's nice to visit this cathedral when you are in luxembourg. Not a very special place. You can burn some candles and it's free of charge. You can donate some money for them.

The Cathedral is right in the hart of the town. You could visit free of charge- make sure that you take appropriate decent clothing. Voluntaries are present in the cathedral and are happy to offer information about the place or concerts and other events in the cathedral.
In short Luxembourg is a treat to visit. Friendly people, lovely restaurants and a variety of places to see. This is a place for a short term trip if you want a view and break type experience.

A lovely peaceful retreat in the heart of the city. The architecture is stunning with beautiful stained glass windows. There are people begging outside the doors - they look intimidating but are no bother to tourists.
Absolutely amazing. The pictures and stained glass windows are incredible. Well worth a visit. Words cannot describe this Cathedral.

As a monarchist and history buff, the Cathedral Notre Dame was without a doubt on my list of places to visit. Being in the centre of the city, it is very easy to reach. It is also something of a guiding point, with its large, dark spires dominating the city's skyline. As a place

Looks fairly uninspiring from the outside buthere is some interesting history just inside the door, some beautiful stained glass windows and if you can negotiate the stairs, it is worth going down into the crypt as there are some interesting fatures down there
The stained glass windows alone are worth seeing. Very impressive. The downstairs chapel is lovely and also houses the royal crypt.
The Notre Dame of Luxemburg cathedral is a hidden gem in the old town. The tapestries and paintings as well as the stained glass windows in the oldest portion of the church are really beautiful.

I've been to many cathedrals in Europe but this one was the most peaceful. Quiet, and tranquil if you go early. We were there in the morning and it was nearly empty with just a few locals praying in the chairs. Beautiful architcture, we'll kept and cleaned. All around incredible!

The charming huge window panes tell a story in themselves and every step within this building is so peaceful, the architectural beauty would change you and it's grandeur will certainly leave a long lasting mark in your memory.

I have to be honest, I've seen more beautiful churches. However, visiting this kind of places (mosque, churches, temple) bring a sense of peace. It just feels different. So yes, I would still recommend this place.
Beautiful church, the workmanship is unreal. Stop and light a candle. Would Recommend seeing it.the location is great right in the city center
The baroque-inspired Notre Dame cathedral has a magnificent main altar with a gilded statue of Mother Mary and is called "Crown of the old town"
A beautiful Cathedral in a beautiful city !! Special treat of a heart shaped piece hanging from the ceiling ! Ever time it moved the light shined thru !!
I was looking forward to this and it did not disappoint.Very Beautiful I have visited Notre Dame in Paris so it was good to compare
An understated interior but saying that beautiful stain glass work. Free to enter. Stonework of entry is very intricate.
Amazing place to see in Luxembourg. Don't pass there without going inside! Is very nice inside and the coloured glass is gorgeous.
The designs in the stain glass windows are great. The rest of the interior feels like a bit of a let down. No access to the tower like some churches have.
Well, it is one more cathedral in Europe... :) It is not like the Notre Dame in paris (which I liked the most) but still worth a visit.
The stained glass is lovely. Try and avoid the tour groups if you can, you will have a far more pleasant visit if you do with more time and space to take in the feeling of the cathedral.
Relatively small by some cathedral standards but beautiful inside. Lovely stained glass. Worth a visit inside if you are passing by.

This is a great church in Old Town. The stained glass is beautiful and there is an area where you can light candles. Definitely recommended if you are in the area as a place to visit, reflect, and take some nice photos.

It's large but not particularly so. The stained glass is good but not outstanding, although the knights at the back are done well. The columns are the most interesting as they have patterns cut into them. It seems to be popular with tour groups. But it's a nice church, a
Notre Dame du Luxembourg is a large cathedral with plaques about the history of the cathedral and the area. If you're walking around the city centre, make sure to drop by here
Likes to visit churches with stained glass works and what a beautiful and calm place.dont compare with the one in Paris just feel the peace
Worth a visit. The stained glass windows let in beautiful light ( not dark like some cathedrals) and the atmosphere is peaceful and contemplative.

was decent and proper. lotsa tourist all the time too. however you will not be impressed if you have seen the notre dames from france(marseille, lyon, strasbourg, paris) worth to take a look though since it's well located and free anyway.
A lovely 'spired' cathedral with beautiful stained glass windows, both old and modern, in the heart of the city. Very peaceful and free to enter. Worth a visit - 30 minutes - an hour.
Beautiful stained glass windows and a very nicely kept cathedral. The usual lighting of candles and works of art
I love visiting churches of all faiths and denominations. This one does not disappoint. We came as part of a walking tour and the guide really knew her stuff to make the visit interesting.

After a month of traveling through Germany, Austria and the Czech Republic and seeing so many churches and cathedrals you start too get a bit blasé but this is one of the most impressive with very beautiful stained glass windows.

It's a cathedral, of course it's worth to have a look. In less than 30 minutes you have seen everything and continue your walk through town. Don't miss the crypta in the lower part and the historic panels next to the stairs that go down.
I was in Luxembourg for the weekend and attended the Sunday morning mass. The cathedral is beautiful with stained glass windows and the music during the mass was exqusite.
This is an impressive building , free to enter. Worth an hour of your time when in Luxembourg. Fantastic stained glass and impressive roof.
Clean, pretty building. Worth a visit & some pictures - whether u r religious or not. Stain glass window is something else.

We visited on a Sunday morning so were half expecting a service to be on, we weren't dissapointed as there was a huge gathering of people worshipping, ( as well as us tourists at the back) it must have been a special mass as later in the day we saw them marching through the
Been to many cities over the years & this was very nice & well worth a visit if you are in the area.

A big gothic structure, really impressive. The altar was a bit fussy for my taste but I did like the fact that it felt like a working cathedral with services proceeding on spite of the heavy tourist presence. Some really impressive archir=tecture - worth a 20 min visit
Doing a partial trip, we came here and we're in awe of the history in this location, overall a must see.

In the heart of the city, so you shouldn't miss it if you are in Luxembourg. As the city center is not so big, you can visit all the main attractions in a day or an afternoon. This cathedral is not so big, but inside it's bigger that I expected. Wonderful place, I really loved!
We saw a service in progress with all the bling and the organ was playing too and with all the colourful glass and icons, it brough the cathedral to life. The decor is outstanding

It seems that there are two types of cathedrals in most Francophone countries – Notre Dammes and Sacre Cours. Well, I couldn't find a Sacre Cour in Luxembourg city, but there was a definitely a Notre Damme, or church of Our Lady. Like many of them, this one is pretty large, and
Like other people have commented; this is a fairly average European cathedral. Not bad, but not great either.
Really nice place. It has got a lot of history. What I enjoy on this kind of attraction is to wonder how people could build it and what kind of skills they had.
a fairly average european cathedral worth a wander if you are in the area but not a lot to see. Interesting tomb in the crypt
The stained glass windows were very impressive. A lovely cathedral to visit. Didn't see any information, but we didn't enter via the main door.

We spent our April Bank Holiday weekend in Luxembourg and managed to visit this beautiful cathedral, very quiet and peaceful. there was a service on so unfortunately we were unable to take any pictures inside but its very well looked after clean and beautiful. id recommend

A very short walk from our hotel so it was a no brainer to visit. Folding church and no close access to the altar. Numerous old fashion.confessional. Nice organ. Much plainer than many European catherals

I have seen a lot of churches and this one doesn't make it to the top 10. The alter and staindglass windows are ok but the rest is pretty standard. The cripte of the royal family however is very beautiful and definatly makes a visit to this church worth while. You only get a

This National Cathedral is very nice. Seats are folding chairs and is quite large. It has old fashioned confessionals and even has a crypt. It is attached to the National Library or biblioteque. It has some interesting items inside.
A very quiet and peaceful cathedral. Nice to pay a visit here whilst visiting Luxembourg. Beautiful building.

Upon entering the building, the map of Luxemburg in former times took me by surprise in terms of the much larger size of the country. The crypt is a very interesting place with some unexpected corners and items. Clearly the most important church in the country.
It was a nice place to visit and as a part of the history of the city very pleasant. I found the crypt most interesting and the mosaic windows in the church nice to look at.
Beautiful Cathedral both inside and out were they still say mass. There is a crypt downstairs were some of the Royal family are buried.
It's a large cathedral in the middle of the city. Some interesting stained glass, etc. Not worth a special trip, but if you are there already a nice side trip.
